3:00 A 300 bar chamber pressure is high, but RD-180 gets over 260 with oxygen-rich closed cycle, while Raptor uses full-flow closed-cycle, so it's not that unrealistic. Specific impulse of 380 seconds is certainly high (no doubt the vacuum value). You can't compare Raptor to RS-25, because RS-25 burns LH2. There are some kerosene burners getting close to 350 seconds in vacuum (e.g. the RD-180 again, and Merlin Vacuum 1-D), so the methane-burning Raptor with its all-round excellence could conceivably hit 380. So yes, the Raptor numbers are terrific, and it's clear from Elon's video that it already can run quite a while without blowing up. Very interesting news, more specific than we have had up to now. Space X are doing truly wonderful stuff.

Honestly, the more weight you can add to a launch, the better. Think about this -  long-term living on Mars is likely going to require heavy equipment for construction. A single, average-weight bulldozer weighs in at 50 tons. If someone designs one that can be powered by lithium cells, hydrogen fuel cells, etc., that weight could be considerably higher.  One thing that is a must for long-term survival, is going underground, or moving sufficient dirt to insulate against radiation.

It could help to have rockets and ships to go back and forth between planets and space ports, but also have people in the Mars space station/port to remotely control robots and drones to do the researches and construction before to be able to land and live on Mars. From the ISS experience, we know we can live for months/years in a space station, so we could apply it for a space station that would be moving to Mars and then be in orbit of Mars. And since it would be big enough to have multiple people, and not just be confined in a BFS for months for the travel time to Mars (like being on a boat cruise, but for months). Also with a large space station, it could allow to not only have scientific, but require different type of jobs, making it more open to more people (not just scientific, astronauts and rich people). Like a submarine or aircraft carrier, there’s still a need for a cook and someone to clean the floor... and so could be a Mega SpaceX “entreprise” Space station/port. My 2 cents

380s ISP is with the vacuum nozzle and still pretty far away from the RS-25 which had a vacuum ISP of 452 seconds. That is a giant difference but is caused by the choice of fuel and not necessarily by the engine. Hydrogen will just always have the best ISP because specific impulse is tied to exhaust velocity and hydrogen has the highest. You simply will not get a methane engine to 450 seconds. Kerosene is even worse. The best hydrogen engine, the RL-10 does 471 seconds in vacuum. Methane is pretty good but not hydrogen so 380 seconds on a non-hydrogen engine is spectacular and so is the chamber pressure which also correlates to ISP but the main thing people are forgetting that it is the first ever full flow staged combustion engine.

Shuttle engines where fuel rich (a lot of fuel is burnt with a small amount of ox to power the pumps and is then fed back into the combustion chamber instead of venting it overboard such as non staged combustion or open loop engines such as Merlin, RS-27 etc... and the Russian engines are oxidizer rich. Raptor is both, it runs an ox rich loop powering the oxygen turbopumps and a fuel rich side pumping the fuel. Both flows combining into the main combustion chamber. Either or has been done, oxidizer rich being considerably more difficult and higher performance while fuel rich gets very efficient but lousy thrust to weight.

Elon should consider putting Dragons in the cargo hold of the BFS.  On return to Earth orbit the crew/passengers could land in the crew certified Dragons and leave the BFS in orbit to serve as a way point, hotel, fuelling depot etc for future missions.  The Earth is such a deep gravity well that landing the whole BFS mass back on Earth seems a profligate waste of resource.  Likewise on Mars missions it might be useful to keep a BFS in Mars orbit and have propulsive Dragons ferry crew and materials to (and maybe from) the surface.

The Shuttle RS-25's sea level Isp is only 366 because it is so overexpanded. In vacuum, the RS-25 and the Raptor are very close to the maximum theoretical Isp of their respective fuel/oxidizer combos which is 460-ish for hydrolox and 386 for methalox.
better looking = more efficient in real talk.

OK... You just made a statement about nozzle pressure. The way I understand it, the pressure inside the nozzle must be able to support the entire weight of the rocket. If the rocket weighs 1000 lbs the nozzle pressure must exceed 1000lbs. Is this a correct interpretation? In addition a ship has a specific frame called a thrust block. It is a block located on a single frame along the length of the shaft where the thrust of the shaft is transferred into the hull of the ship. Does a rocket have a similar arrangement to move the force of the thrust higher up the rocket towards the Center of gravity?
